The famous American physician, born in Japan, Dr Alexander Leaf, went around the world with his wife in, I believe, the late 1950s or early 60s. He went to all of the so-called blue zones on the planet.

His conclusion was that longevity has little to do with one special kind of diet or set of nutrients. Longevity has to do with two things. The cultural embrace and veneration of elderly people. The second thing he discovered was to what extent people fit into their food niche depending upon where they lived.

That is to say, for health and long life, eat according to the food environment in which you were born and raised.

An Eskimo would not do well eating a tropical diet. Conversely someone from Ecuador in the Amazon would not do well living on whale and seal blubber.

Dr Sinclair is a VERY controversial figure. His findings about SIRT2 have been shown to maybe be true in the lab but certainly NOT in the living bodies.
I urge people to consider the YT science with a grain of salt. In the end, Sinclair is a businessman who's made a very good living on the promise of his initial scientific findings, but these date back 2003 and no amount of research done since then has been able to translate into a useable drug or technique for animals or human beings.

When a Harvard guy like Sinclair talks, we feel like he is legitimate and we should listen. But actually scientists have opposed him, publishing papers showing that Sinclair was wrong.
Please check out Dr Brad Stanfield here on YT for more information.

I urge Veritasium to do stricter background research when introducing this kind of topic. At the very least, the contradictarians should have been included in this video and Sinclair confronted with his absolute lack of result for the past 20 years. He says his body has aged back, but there's no demonstrable way to give an age with a lab test. The test in question was conducted by a private sector company which Sinclair has strong ties with...

Some people completely misunderstand what intermittent fasting truly is. Most would think you're starving yourself, or reducing the amount of caloric intake you ingest. When in reality, true intermittent fasting is prolonging the time period between your last meal and break•fast meal, and also reducing the amount of times you eat in your day(snacking, multiple meals, etc). You can easily intake the same amount of calories while intermittent fasting. It may feel like you're starving @ 1st, but once your body's hunger hormones adapt to the changes, and is much easier to do than the mind thinks when it comes to real starvation

I would consider the content in this video to be highly suspicious and maybe even deceptive. Scientific skepticism requires us to check our sources, question the integrity of the data, and never use words like 'cure' 'solve' or 'reverse'. This video breaks all three of these rules. The doctor's research is  peer reviewed but we have seen peer reviewed papers before that amount to very little. The integrity of his research has yet to be upheld, and it would benefit greatly from using multiple sources. Remember to conduct your own research, read up on the person that is trying to educate you. Doubt every claim that is presented as absolute truth, and scrutinize data at every level.

Years ago, when I was about 15 or so, I spoke with a scientist with the S.E.N.S. Foundation. He basically touched on everything you did here in this video. I asked him about the possibility of slowing, stopping, and/or even reversing aging. And he basically said that even if we unlocked that ability through study and scientific measures, it wouldn't prevent death by accidents, or by diseases, viruses or bacteria. In fact, in prolonging our lifespan even by an extra 100 years, we would double our chances of dying horribly. That's the biggest drawback.

Just think of how much has happened in the past 2 years alone; covid, shootings, political posturing, war, fear-mongering, increases in mental illness, a possible recession, etc. Now ask yourself if you truly want to live double your life span and deal with similar things in the future, if not *worse*.

As a kid I loved the idea of living forever. But if you live forever, everyone you know will die and you'll never truly be able to make deep and meaningful connections.

Part of what makes life so special is that it is brief, and it has an end. You never know when your death will happen, which makes you want to do your best, and be your best.

Time and again, all the evidence suggests that the "easiest" way to extend life is to eat just enough to stay alive and healthy and to eat less often. Epigenomic information theory of aging

Loss of information epigenome
ㄴ Derived from the Greek “epi” meaning “above”, the epigenome describes modifications to the genome that do not affect the DNA sequence but determine whether genes are switched on or off where and when they are needed.

Requires the protein histone that the DNA is wrapped on
Methylation - Chemical signaling markers on the DNA

When Chromosomes are damaged, they're unfolded, stitched and folded back, in the process, histones are left in weird places and methylation may be added

Longevity Genes
1. Sirtuins - control information in genes
silent information regulator.

senses how much energy we're taking in, mostly in the firm of sugar

I'd be cautious about the protein restriction; lots of evidence out there that the negative effects outweigh benefits. Restriction should be periodic (i.e. during fasting) vs. chronic, which will cause all sorts of health issues. Protein turns on MTOR, sure, but acutely. Long-term you need protein to keep your body healthy. Similarly, exercise has acute effects that look horrible on paper as well, but the body's response to the exercise (hormesis) has innumerable benefits.

In terms of the five (six strategies) for increased life span/decrease your biological age, the extreme cold/heat strategies should be active for sauna lovers in colder climate (Finland, Sweden, Norway). For some (myself included) this ceremony almost becomes like a drug, and I know a lot of people who actually do this at least 5-7 times a week during the autumn/winter/spring. I am fully convinced that we're one of the last few generations that will have to deal with imminent death. Somewhere, in the future, people will have the option to stay immortal unless fatal ijuries happen.
Immortality is a curse, it brings many other issues but it is nonetheless an exciting prospect. If you could apply this to astronauts, you could conceivably send them on a seemingly endless voyage to another galaxy and have it be manned by the same group of people from earth to destination. The term "we won't see this in our lifetimes" would be an old relic and people will be learning about the times where living to 100 years old was considered a "blessing" and they'll laugh.
At the same time, being immortal, you're not pressed for time, you can always start learning a new thing tomorrow or a year later or a decade later... Your dreams aren't going anywhere. It could be the age of stagnancy. Not to mention serious regulations would have to be put in place for childbirth. Perhaps when you're ready to leave the plane of existence, you'd be allowed to have children, raise them and then ultimately end your life in some way. And people will inevitably get to that point because no matter how exciting it may seem to live forever, it is also very depressing. Maybe we're the blessed ones that get to experience a natural life cycle still.
It's always interesting to think about this stuff.

Most of what Sinclair says is true in regards to experimental results, but it is also misleading. He doesn't understand aging in that he can "reverse" it in the way he implies. Show me the mice that live as long as Brandt's bats, let alone naked mole rats or even humans. Mice lifespan has been manipulated for decades. Yes, there are different, arguably better, ways to do it now, but there still isn't anything close to a successful "theory of everything" for aging, despite what Sinclair states about epigenome.

He will occasionally mention counter/failed evidence that exists--whether for resveratrol or calorie restriction--but he doesn't adapt his overarching views on aging to accommodate the whole evidence. I've seen him mention iron multiple times, which is nice since most scientists do not, but I have never seen him mention methionine restriction or polyunsaturated fat content of tissues. He talks about insulin resistance vaguely, like a nutritionist, rather than a rigorous scientist. If "insulin resistance" is so bad, why does FIRKO mouse live ~20% longer?

People hear a Harvard scientist pontificate, and because much of the content to them is unverifiable and/or unknown, they assume it is fact, because "scientists are fact discoverers" or something. They do make discoveries, but they're also dependent on the popularity and commercial value of their work, regardless of its truth or predictive power. He pushes several ideas that line up with large mainstream/corporate interests: for example, the "Mediterranean diet." So on one hand we need highly controlled objective experimentation, but then it's okay to adamantly support a diet based on retroactively chosen groups and endpoints, which yield weak-ish correlations? ...Ha, what integrity.

I've been Vegan™ for 12 years and one thing I noticed over the years is that I simply don't get sick anymore. No stomach aches, no runny noses, nothing except the odd light headache after stress... I just avoid the typical Western diet. In a way I find it weird, but I also look far younger than my age. I am in my early 30s and am often confused for a 19 year old (most recent estimate). I'm often surprised by how different other people look born in the same year as me. Part of me thinks I just lucked out with good genes (I also have dark skin which might help), because sometimes I do eat a lot of plant foods from time to time (Greek hummus, Indian curries, unsalted crackers, PB&J, Kale, Cilantro, Pistachios, Legumes, Ginger, Vegan Burritos) but I definitely think others should consider going plant based and see if they get similar results.

Also, I also strongly avoid candies, sodas/pop, and sweets. I drink A LOT of Itoen Japanese tea and water (no sugar). I do occasionally have oreos or nutri-grain bars with oatmilk or soymilk when I'm in the mood for more sugar, but that's not often, and when I do eat it I always plan to walk or dance to music afterwards. I don't exercise much, so I imagine I could get even better health-span mileage. I do occasionally drink wines and Japanese alcohol, but don't like beers. PS: It's fascinating that too much protein accelerates ageing... I feel like I get plenty of that with my diet. Makes me happy that I never got sucked into macho "real men eat meat" or military bro culture. lol

Its resources are finite and this fact alone makes endeavors to make the most greedy, ambitious, irresponsible, savage, and dangerous species on the planet biologically immortal unconscionable. Do this, and in less than 200 years, the majority of the surface of this planet will be paved over with asphalt and concrete.

I notice that the creator of this video seemed rather flippant about the use of resources and production of waste as valid objection to the continued pursuit of this objective. My guess is he, like many of those posting here, believe we can rely on science to overcome any obstacles. For those of you who fall into this category, bear in mind that our technology has not really advanced in 40 years. Computer technology still uses transistors in the same deployment; binary remains the only way to code computers, we still use magnetic storage. We still use gutted viruses to make vaccines and the pathways to discover how to develop them are largely the same, with minor tweaks. Agriculture still requires arable land, fertilization, pest control, and massive amounts of water - and, on this topic, the public fears genetically modified food. It is therefore unwise to place such faith in science. Science still hasn't found a sustainable way to remove atmospheric carbon, clean the oceans, or neutralize toxic waste produced by nuclear technologies that continue to pile up.

I am not a religious person and have an immense amount of trust in science, but only when science pursues good aims and human biological immortality is not one of them. Abandon this research. Unless you plan to sterilize those who undergo such a procedure, it is a hard no from me.

There was a study in Science magazine in the early 90s that studied two groups of several different animal populations, overfed (fat), and underfed (lean). Both populations had an average lifespan, and a maximum life span. The average for the lean population was the maximum for the fat group, and the two times the fat group average was the maximum for the lean group. Applying that to humans they suggested if humans were lean their average life would be 120 yrs and the maximum would be 150.

What is aging? Why do we age? Does a healthy diet help? Should we wear sunscreen? Why do things help us live longer?

When we go outside the sun breaks apart our dna.We see the dna damage as why we age. New studies coming out show something a little different.

When our dna is damaged, it tries to rebuild itself. Since the dna is damaged, the epigenome/what houses and activates the dna, takes this role on rebuilding.

99% of the time it succeeds, and the other 1% is aging. What is thought is your dna cells forget what type of cell they are, although they/you are all the same dna. You have skin cells, brain cells, hair, etc. although they should rebuild the same everytime, they dont. We develope hair where it shouldnt be. Grey hair too. And develop other symptoms as well. So should we control the amount of activation of the epigenome/protect the epigenome if that is what effects aging?

First we have to test it.

The interesting part about bacterial evolution and how we tie in, is the development of bacterias two ways of life. A "grow and reproduce" and a "protect and repair". These dormant genes are triggered by physiological changes. Fires for example.

The 3 types of longevity genes in the epigenome are key to "longevity". they control the general "defensive measures".

The 3: information genes that rebuild. Amino acid regulator genes for eating meats and the glucose genes for energy lvls.
These genes turn on and off things. They tell us hidden things like how low cellular glucose lvls means we are tired and hungry. Hot vs cold.

By controlling the cellular controls we can make aging happen faster or slower.

So now scientist are experimenting on animals. It is hard to control/protect all portions of the epigenome.

Scientist first want to see if they can increase aging to test their theory. by creating a mouse that is susceptible to minor minor gene damage where it repairs 99% vs mutates, they tested their theory.


As it turns our, its just like the doc tells you. By turning on your cellular defenses, it protects the epigenome and reduces aging. So in our mice/rats and monkeys, they dramatically reduced aging by introducing intermittent fasting/reducing the amount of time they eat, calories, limiting amino acid intake, and to keep it a little bit cool.

Does this mean fish is bad? Why do some islands in japan have the highest life expectancy? Green tea, cigarettes, and fresh fish? So many questions.

What if we made a controlled experiment, where monkeys were cholericly restricted and cooled, vs a gluttonous monkey group that was able to eat whatever they wanted.

They did and the skinny and fit group way out performed the other.

What next what if we developed a molecule that acted as a inhibitor to activate our defenses without "fasting".

Well we have! (For mice) A very very old mouse ran over 3km, 50% further than any mouse they tested, way out performing the untreated. They compared it to a 70 neating a 20yr old in a marathon by 50%.


So now we are left with us. Isnt this evolutions, and darwinism? The physiological changes Darwin saw in the Galapagos, pushed animals to develop. Now we have a "serum" in the works the works for us.


So
#1 avoid dna damage. Xrays, sun, anything that damages or changes your dna.

#2 eat less :-/

#3 eat less protein

#4 high intensity exercise training

#5 be hot or cold ( must sweat or chill) this could be just not wearing a jacket in winter.

If we take away aging from our species, we'll seriously worsen a main evolutionary trait, which is adaptability by recombination, i.e. procreation of new individuals that may be better adapted to the ecosystem than its predecessors. It's diminishing our collective changes out of selfishness. Plus, people born in poorer parts of the world will end up at the wrong end of the equation, as usual.
But will this only cause overpopulation?

“The point of this video is ‘can we’ slow aging in humans.”  This is an ongoing problem within scientific fields that is often criticized.  The primary question should not be “can we,” but must always be “should we.”  Can we blow up the entire planet?  Sure, that’s an interesting scientific challenge to undertake.  But if we ignore the more important question of “should we,” we just might succeed in finding a way that some crazy, unstable person just might actually implement.  Can we build nuclear weapons?  Sure. Should we?  Can we build biological weapons of mass destruction that kill indiscriminately?  Should we?  In the same way, it is actually critically important to ask should we extend human life indefinitely, without first asking “should we?”  Or, at the very least, identifying what the risks are in doing so and figuring out how to solve those real problems before even proceeding with answering the question “can we.”

On the side comment regarding transferring human consciousness into computers, the biggest problem is not that we are technologically far from transferring consciousness into a computer.  The real problem is that whole concept relies on a highly questionable philosophical assumption of monism.  That the Mind = the Brain. It boils down to whether or not monism or dualism is actually true.  If the brain is merely the primary interface between the corporeal body and incorporeal mind, in much the same way as the CPU is the central processing system that translates inputs from external to the computer into different behaviors within the computer, and different output signals from the computer to the external user, then transferring consciousness by simply mapping neurons would never work.  And there is no evidential reason for concluding that the mind is the brain, while there are solid philosophical arguments against this assumption, as well as a lot of evidentiary reasons drawn from scientific experiments for questioning that assumption.  Neurology has had many revealing experiments over the centuries that undermine monism in favor of dualism.

"Two models of living" is actually The Disposable Soma Theory by Thomas Kirkwook (1977).

SIR2/SIRT2 (orthologs) actually acetylates and activates FOXO (a transcription factor that essentially regulates transcription of longevity associated genes - ie anti-inflammatory, etc. and represses transcription of genes involved in fat storage and insulin like molecule production). SIR2/SIRT2 are NAD+ dependent so they cannot activate FOXO without NAD+ present.

Caloric restriction studies (by NIA) on Rhesus Monkeys did not show a significant increase in lifespan (however the monkeys did LOOK better phenotypically) but they did show a repression in age-related pathologies (cancer, diabetes, but NOT cardiovascular disease).

Additionally, higher temperatures actually increase speed of aging as they correlate with higher rates of metabolism which leads to higher levels of reactive oxygen species (damage DNA - especially the ends of telomeres - this signals a DNA damage which activates p53 which leads to cell cycle arrest or apoptosis)

But an active person who eats well would only have to make make minor tweaks.

1. Avoid too much sun and damaging chemicals

2. Eat less protein (you definitely still need it) maybe enough for your bodyweight in one meal.

3. Intermittent fasting

4. The being comfortably hot or cold thing is tricky because they did not say for how long each day and the exact extent. And generally these people already enjoy a longer and healthier life than those who put forth zero effort.

so, if we do discuss things like wealth inequality and too much population growth:
first of all, I think if we make this technology something that you need a doctor's referral to get, we could prioritize people who are aging prematurely (namely people with certain degenerative diseases and other disabilities). unfortunately, the society we're in right now has a tendency to put disabled people at the last possible priority, so I don't think that would happen.
but second of all, if we were to slow or even reverse aging in actually old people, I don't think we need to worry that much more about the population. sure, there will be fewer people dying and therefore the population will increase faster, but 1) old age isn't the only (or even the most common iirc) way for people to die, so people will still be dying and 2) at least for people with ovaries, increasing the years in one's life and even in one's health doesn't necessarily increase the years in their reproductive ability. human eggs are formed in the womb, so when someone is born they don't grow any more. it also probably wouldn't stop older people from having higher chances of miscarriages and babies that die almost right away (due to chromosomal abnormalities), because this is a result of their eggs specifically (well, the precursor to eggs, I forgot the actual name) being paused in the middle of a cell cycle for so long. ie, it's not the age of the person, but rather the age of the egg. I think it could be possible to increase (or at least stop the decrease) in virility of people with sperm, but I don't think that would necessarily mean out-of-control population growth, because hopefully the number of people for whom that works that are going out and knocking up young people would be minimal.

It's sad that so many people are content w bashing the doctor for doing his research and doing what he can to live his best life.

At 39 years-old, I was obese and suffering from disabling depression and anxiety. I had been this way for as long as I can remember. It was so bad that I was receiving SSDI at the time. I was suicidal and at my wit's end. I had heard of the incredible, life-changing benefits that could be had through intermittent fasting in conjunction w periodic 72-120 hr fasts and supplementation. I went all-in, thinking that I'd give it a go for 30 days and then kill myself. That was 3-years and over 100 lbs ago. I'm no longer on SSDI and antidepressants, and I'm happier and healthier than I've ever been.

It is true that through fasting we reach a state of autophagy. Autophagy allows for cell-recycling and intracellular rejuvenation. Production of growth hormone, stem cells, mitochondria and gene-expression go through the roof! In fact, every single gene that contributes to the production of antioxidants is expressed. Thus, reducing the likelihood of dementia, Alzheimer's, arthritis, cancer and other diseases associated w aging. There's so much more to this it's silly not everyone is doing it. A Japanese doctor won the Nobel Prize in 2016 for his research on autophagy and it's anti-aging benefits.

Don't believe me? Do your own due diligence. Or don't. I don't care. I'm just putting it out there for those of you who truly want to live a longer, healthier and happier life.

According to a recent study by Johns Hopkins, more than 250,000 people in the United States die every year because of medical mistakes, making it the third leading cause of death after heart disease and cancer.

Other studies report much higher figures, claiming the number of deaths from medical error to be as high as 440,000. The reason for the discrepancy is that physicians, funeral directors, coroners and medical examiners rarely note on death certificates the human errors and system failures involved. Yet death certificates are what the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention rely on to post statistics for deaths nationwide.

Let's look at mammalian reproduction.  We all look at it as if an entirely new life,  hosted by females. I know my evidence might be just anecdotal, but I've been taking a precursor to NAD+ called Nicotinamide Riboside at a 300mg daily dose orally for 3 months (I started May 9th 2020 and these were my benefits 3 months later). My current biological age is 19 years old. Here's my timeline so far in terms of benefits:

Since my start, it took my body 2 and a half weeks to adapt to the change and feel any benefits but then I woke up one day roughly 2 weeks later and had plenty of energy. This baffled me since that night I only got 5 hours of sleep. With all of this energy, I wasn't hyper but more clearer-minded and restful. I would go as far as to say I felt like I had the same energy as I did when I was 12.

After those 2 and a half weeks, the next big change for me was constantly dreaming. For 9 straight days, I had at least 2 dreams per night which was unheard of for me and I was low key excited for what would happen next. During this time, I noticed how after lunchtime around midday, I didn't have a drop in energy. Previously, I had attended school and as soon as my lunch break had ended and I made it to the next period, I used to get a wave of lethargy and often dozed off to sleep for a quick power nap. What happened next really changed me. Due to my sleep schedule fixing itself gradually, my circadian rhythm was fixing itself and I had begun to feel tired earlier which took me by surprise.

Following this abundant change, about a week later I noticed that I would watch Netflix shows and YouTube in a whole different way. Before this experiment for myself, I would most of the time watch a show and remember some details unless something drastic happened in what I was watching or doing in general but something changed. My memory of recollecting what had happened was so much better as now I wouldn't just remember minor details but I would be able to remember the characters names even a couple months after watching the show. In my day-to-day life, my improved memory helped me remember orders I would write down since I'm the "Uber Eats" for the family, driving to and from restaurants and picking up food for us.

Going forward, I recently started taking this other oral supplement called Resveratrol that David Sinclair also takes which I'll have to do more research on. I know this is all anecdotal evidence and it's not concrete evidence but these have been the benefits 3 months into taking this NAD+ booster as supplementation. Since the start, these benefits felt like they have compounded as I feel incredible!

Once I stopped taking Nicotinamide Riboside (NR) from TruNiagen, I followed up with taking the larger molecule Nicotinamide Mononucleotide (NMN) sublingual in 600mg doses daily for the next 7 months. During that time, I noticed that I didn’t have any stomach cramps like I did while taking NR by Tru Niagen; in fact, the NMN that I took sublingually (under the tongue) had lemon flavoring so it was a nice mid-day treat!

As of this week, I ordered NAD+ supplementation through Alive By Science on their website. The shipment should get to my house in the next few days I can’t wait! I ordered a new type of supplementation absorption method which is called ‘Liposomal NAD+’ on their website and it utilizes a phospholipid shield which surrounds the active ingredient (NAD+ precursors) so it won’t get broken up in the stomach and can be absorbed ‘3-5 times better’ than traditional supplements which use pills. I plan on taking their Transdermal skin products that have NAD+ in them too so I can get rid of sun damage on my hands. I’m thoroughly excited to try this out so I can extend my health and lifespan!

Feel free to ask me any questions at all about anything I mentioned or if you’re curious about anything! Since the start, these benefits felt like they have compounded as I feel incredible! Thanks for reading the script for my YouTube comment Ted Talk :)

It is exciting, but it is also scary. I am all for advancing science and technology, but we often find that other aspects of our society lag. There will be consequences that we need to figure out how to deal with. If birth rates don't change, population will explode. We have certain ages at which people are expected to retire, and then programs like Social Security are paid for by those still in the working age range, but if life expectancy dramatically increases, the ratio of workers to retirees plummets, and the older members of society will become an increasing financial burden on the younger working age population. Will we greatly increase retirement age to compensate? Will we reduce benefits? Will we be able to make Modern Monetary Theory work well enough? (Even that only works theoretically for countries with a certain set of conditions, so it is not a global solution.)

If we rush ahead with the science before other elements are ready, we could be creating hugely disastrous outcomes.

Evolution is driven by suitability to the environment, contained by energy and what is physically possible or likely. Since the environment changes most organisms have evolved to enhance variety so that changes in the environment will not cause a species to go extinct. This is the one of the reasons sex and sexes evolved.

As a necessary requirement to survive a changing environment a speices must have two things: 1. A variety of individuals and 2. Regular changing of those individuals to avoid an evolutionary cul-du-sac.

We die to ensure this variety and change and so we don't compete with the young and therefore keep the ability of the species to adapt to a changing environment high. That is, we die because we are programmed to die. Virtually all species have life spans almost exactly the length to ensure their offspring are also able to reproduce. This is not an accident.

As an individual we may want to live forever, or at least a long time. As a species, it is demonstrably a bad idea.

It's a curious study. But while avoiding "other" criteria you've created a paradox. You cannot discuss aging in a vacuum. The age of a species is an evolutionary outcome within a given range of various parameters, including population, relative health span of adults, age profile and death rates of infants, etc. Modern medical devices hugely impact those factors and changing balance and as consequence, the natural health span will most likely be reduced. Bar any loopholes in our biology that evolution had overlooked, you need to become a jellyfish to live longer. Here is how another study expresses the same: Species longevity has been determined and conserved by millions of years of evolution and hence cannot be significantly improved, whatever we do. It is true that millions of years of evolution have resulted in longevity and health assurance systems of amazing complexity and efficacy. Although these systems cannot be perfect, it is extremely unlikely that in the foreseeable future we will be able to significantly improve such systems when their performance is at its peak. The rest of the causes of longevity presented is circumstantial. It's a biological viewpoint so to speak. You might as well visit blue zones and discover that eating healthy food and having some genetic predisposition is a guarantee of longevity of the locals. But this is not what you would call a replicable study.

When analyzing this relationship between the mouse and human studies, researchers determined that “the results are surprising, and almost embarrassing: the correlation is not only weak, but in many areas of study it is practically non-existent. In rodents, resveratrol decreased cardiovascular risk factors, improved cardiovascular function and physical capacity, and decreased inflammation, that is, it improved vascular function. More specifically, combining resveratrol with sports training destroyed the reductions in blood pressure, cholesterol, and triglycerides often associated with training; it had a more constricting effect on the arteries than a dilator; and "led to a significantly smaller increase in exercise-induced oxygen uptake."
Rodents taking resveratrol perform better in sports, but in humans, resveratrol produces a 45% decrease in maximal aerobic capacity. Although perhaps the problem is resveratrol supplementation, that is, giving study subjects capsules with 50 times more resveratrol than would be found in foods such as grapes, berries, peanuts or chocolate.

Nature uses an optimization strategy when it comes to keeping us alive -- in terms of what to continually replace and what to repair.  So in effects our bodies are design to fall apart all at once.  So to significantly increase human lifespan it would be necessary to use technology to continually replace and repair all the things are bodies won't.  This would require sophisticated nanotechnology and a lot of energy, probably equivalent to two or three times the energy in the food we eat.  Or it would require potentially rewriting our genetic code -- a dangerous tactic -- to enable ourselves to repair and replace what are bodies are not programmed to do.

It has always been reported that people who lived a hard life aged faster. If you look at poverty for instance. Underfed with less protein, too cold in winter and too hot in summer because of inadequate housing, cells are always in survival mode and people age faster and died younger. Or if you look at people who live in harsh environments, like beyond the Arctic Circle, or scorching deserts, they aged and died quicker. There's that saying about life in the Saudi desert. It was "nasty, brutal and short" because food and shelter were so hard to get. Presumably life expectations became longer in the 20th century, particularly in North America, because life became easier. So what is it I don't understand here?

Hear me out: We're meant to die, we were built to break.

You and I have an expiration date, the same as our pets, our parents, our world, the star that breathes life into said world, the galaxy that churns said star-- we are all built to perish one way or another, like part of a machine. Imagine, just for a moment... The Universe is much larger than just us, this you know. Sooo... What if we're some sort of cog in someone or some*things* grand (or not so grand, we could be a space coffee maker for all we know.) machine? Could we really just be photons in somebody's light bulb? Burning and burning until we meet our expiration date-- our obsolescence date? Could be that the meaning of our existence is to provide a sort of fuel for someone else's. We're practically coded to behave according to plan. For some reason, we have a set of rules to follow, a guided path, laws, patterns, regulations... We're cogs in our own machine, could it be that we were built to behave this way? Evolving, living, dying, fighting to progress, progressing only to fight, and all of this... To meet an impenetrable glass ceiling where it is impossible to determine what the substance of the human mind truly consists of and thus inevitably meet a mortal fate?

Wonder for a moment if we could in fact have been conceived to specifically meet our demise. You see, sometime not so soon for you and me, our star will grow dim, our forests will breathe no more, our oceans will freeze over, our cities will have crumbled and our family photos will be nothing more than dust, it seems finite when I put it like that, doesn't it? It's as if it was designed to be so. Like it's depicted in something bigger than we as a race could ever hope to fathom. As seen in a vast and incredibly immense consciousness's blueprint. Perhaps our world holds meaning, just not enough to make a true difference for us as a species. Maybe our sole and true purpose is to heat somebody else's living room or something, for all we know, that could very well be the case. But one thing's for certain, and that is: You smell stinky. Get pranked, goodbye. :)

David Sinclair’s past research on resveratrol has been heavily disputed by other scientists. My understanding is that he claimed that the compound extended the lifespan of laboratory mice, but subsequent studies that were more meticulously designed failed to replicate these results. Not only that, but the popularity of his research led to him earning $720 million in a sale to a pharmaceutical company. He has a financial interest in generating buzz around his work.

I’m not saying there’s nothing to his work or he’s a complete fraud, but he has a history of overstating the potential of a specific anti-aging treatment, and then profiting off of it. Be careful about who you interview for your videos. As a YouTube channel communicating science to the public, you have a responsibility to ensure that you’re not amplifying exaggerated claims, because your audience will believe it. Science is a slow process and a great scientist will speak in a very reserved and measured way about their work, rather than jumping to conclusions. I’m not a scientist myself and can’t judge the accuracy of what he’s saying here, but I fear it’s probably a bit sensationalized. The only way I knew about any of this, though, is because I asked my father, who is a scientist, about this man. Most of your viewers will not have a personal connection to someone with scientific training to add some skepticism to what they’ve seen.

I share the appeal of wanting a better or more dignified ageing process, so as to not live the last 5-10 years of your life bedridden or unable to perform basic tasks. The tips he gave about HIIT, limit sun exposure, be a little hot/cold, etc are great to try to achieve that, but what would be de point of resetting your whole organism so as to be forever young? I know that for some people that sounds like a dream come true, but if you are 70 and you reverse your whole body to feel (and look?) like a 20 year old, you'd be ok with it the first few years but then you'd feel doomed for having to do it all over again. And even if there are some people who feel perfectly fine with reaching 80 years old and then clocking back to 20 as if they were just going to the bakery to get bread, is it ethical to the world and future generations? I'm not trying to be solemn about it, it's just that I can't imagine how there would be enough resources for everyone. How are supposed, let's say, newly graduated doctors to ever get a job when there are hundreds of '80 years olds' who have way more experience than them and they now have the energy and sharpness of a 20 year old? A true answer in today's world would be 'let them compete and let the best one win'. Sure, I support competition, it's what's made the world less poor each year that passes, but I think we all support competition only when it's given under fair circumstances for all and no one really has the complete and full upper hand. Well, that wouldn't be the case with the doctors' example.

So the old theory(10 years old or so) for reducing the speed of aging was that the growth hormones triggered by among other things eating proteins makes the telomeres of cells shorter, and thus making us age faster.

The new theory how-ever is saying that we better maintain our epigenome by among other things reducing intake of amino acids.

In either case eating less protein seems to reduce the speed of aging. And to think that in the big discussion of diet between the people who are scared of fat and the people who are scared of carbohydrates, the one thing they all agreed on was that protein was good.

Also worth noting is that the Okinawa diet - which for a long time has been credited with giving them the longest lifespans on the planet - had considerately reduced intake of animal protein. Their consumption of meat was very rare, while fish although being a little less rare was still lower than the rest of Japan.

Nothing specifically, still but I remember I was happy.
Most of the people that loved me were definitely dead by that time.
I probably mourned them.
Then I moved on.
There were some many already and so many more would come.
At that point I started to realize that, yet I hadn't fully internalized it. I'm sure.
I think... I traveled.
Wanted to see the world.
I remember it only being one world back then.
Back in the good old time as some people from an eternity ago would call it.
I was happy on my journey.
Did I work? Where I got my money from? Did I eat? I don't really know anymore.
I THINK back then I still ate.
Can't recall when I stopped.
Maybe in my 500s or something.
Oh, but I remember by 400s.
Some time back then we left the solar system for the first time.
I was excited.
The implications.
But the days between transmissions from the... What was it called? The Eternity? It doesn't matter.
There were fewer and fewer transmissions and then it stopped.
But in the blink of an eye we had the next mission to spread humanity out there. 20 years? Maybe 30.
But we were determined.
I remember the first colony.
Alpha Centauri if I'm correct.
I couldn't wait to get there.
Wandering earth for over 300 years I had gotten a bit bored.
I spent a couple of hundred years traveling between the new colonies that were established one by one.
It took more than one human lifetime to get from one to the other.
I watched people being born. Grow. And then die.
Many faces.
All faded.
I remember there being a war but I lost interest in current epoch.
I was obsessed with human history.
It had doubled or tripled from back when I was born. There was a lot of knowledge and wisdom to learn from.
That kept me occupied for a couple of years.
My next real memory is from what?
My 1700s?
Our first contact.
I think I was part of it.
If I felt back then as I feel now, I was probably bored and looking for new discoveries.
I remember language being the largest barrier.
Did they even speak?
But we somehow managed.
And others followed.
Almost as many civilizations as stars in the night sky.
Some rose. Some fell.
I watched. Trying to keep out of it.
I think there was a short time where I tried my hand at being a guide and wanted to unite all of them.
That didn't go entirely as planned.
But it didn't matter.
A couple of wars and hundred of years later there it was.
A unified galaxy.
Art. Philosophy. Technology.
We thrived.
There was no more us.
No more them.
There was only we. United.
The entire galaxy one hive.
Guided by an unbound will to progress.
What my home country was to me back in my infancy the galaxy was to us now.
Somewhere along this time part of us started to merge with machines.
We let them.
I remember milkdromeda.
Our hives quickly merged.
Both of us having long lost any use for war.
But after thousands of years I got bored again and left the hive.
I stepped away from progressing forever onward.
I again traveled.
I left our galaxy.
Just set out into space and... Went.
I drifted for an eternity.
Alone on the void.
I think I found other galaxies.
All of them teeming with live.
I watched. Studied.
Some were tribes some had formed one galaxy spreading consciousness.
All of them had names.
None I remember.
At some point the distance between galaxies had become too vast to travel and I decided to remain where I was.
Spent another couple trillion years here.
Mostly bored. What could I do?
There was just this little spec of dust for me to watch.
It should have driven me mad.
Then this galaxy also started to drift apart.
Horror gripped me.
Generations were born and died but for me? It was mere seconds.
I watched it dissolve.
I picked my favorite solar system.
I stayed there for a while.
But I knew it was only temporary.
Its people had become like a friend to me during these last moments.
Until the system started to die.
In the end I was left with a cold, round rock in vast emptiness.
When it's bonds would dissolve, so would mine.
But for one more second this rock was all the memory I had of a homeworld I was born on.
A galaxy I grew up in.
And a universe in which I would die.

WARNING : A potential downside of NAD+ supplementation as a dietary approach for antiaging. The health promises of boosting an important metabolic molecule may be clouded by its possible role in promoting cancer-cell growth. Rugang Zhang of the Wistar Institute, and his colleagues found that in cells entering senescence, rising levels of NAMPT (a major NAD+-producing enzyme in mammals) encourage the release of inflammatory and potentially protumor molecules. Consistent with those findings, mice genetically predisposed toward pancreatic cancer developed more precancerous and cancerous lesions when they consumed the NAD+ precursor NMN. Zhang says more research is needed to fully understand the role of NAD+ in cancer, but he adds that “we should be cautious and bear in mind the potential downside of NAD+ supplementation as a dietary approach for antiaging.” https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/cancer-research-points-to-key-unknowns-about-popular-antiaging-supplements/ NAD+metabolism governs the proinflammatory senescence-associated secretome https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6448588/ A ‘Fountain Of Youth’ Pill? Sure, If You’re A Mouse. Despite his enthusiasm, published scientific research has not yet demonstrated the molecule works in humans as it does in mice. Sinclair, however, has a considerable financial stake in his claims being proven correct, and has lent his scientific prowess to commercializing possible life extension products known as NAD+ boosters and Sirtuin activators. “None of this is ready for prime time. The bottom line is I don’t try any of these things,” said Felipe Sierra, the director of the division of aging biology at the National Institute on Aging at NIH. “Why don’t I? Because I’m not a mouse.” History is replete with examples of cures that worked on mice but not in people. “Many interventions that seem sensible on the basis of research in animals turn out to have unexpected effects in man,” https://khn.org/news/a-fountain-of-youth-pill-sure-if-youre-a-mouse/ SIRTs are involved in many important biological processes and play a critical role in cancer initiation, promotion, and progression. Dual Tumor Suppressor and Tumor Promoter Action of Sirtuins in Determining Malignant Phenotype. https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6363704/ Numerous reports indicate that SIRT1 also has cancer-promoting functions which include inhibition of senescence and of apoptosis in c-Myc- and in PML-driven cancers [21, 22]. Rejuvenating Sirtuins: The Rise of a New Family of Cancer Drug Targets https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3549556/ Something else to consider if your thinking about taking Sirtuin activators, SIRT1 deacetylates RORyt and enhances Th17 cell generation. The balance of effector and regulatory T cell function, dependent on multiple signals and epigenetic regulators, is critical to immune self-tolerance. Dysregulation of T helper 17 (Th17) effector cells is associated with multiple autoimmune diseases, including multiple sclerosis. These findings reveal an unexpected proinflammatory role of SIRT1 and, importantly, support the possible therapeutic use of SIRT1 'inhibitors' against autoimmunity. https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4419343/pdf/JEM_20132378.pdf

Memories work the same way vision works.  Photons hit our retina and our brain learns over the time that we're infants to interpret that stimuli into understandable information.  With memories, I think, every experience lights up 1000's or millions of different parts of the brain and over time our brain learns to interpret those patterns as memories.  Every experience creates a unique pattern of stimulation in the brain, like a fingerprint.  No two ppl or two experiences will ever have the same pattern in the brain.  I don't think memories are stored exactly.  They are just the combination of millions of neurons firing in a pattern that includes neurons that typically control our 5 senses.  A memory is like an after image on an old crt that has been unplugged.  I guess the "keys" to these combinations of lit up neurons must be stored somewhere though, but I don't think memories are stored in some kind of hard drive in one location of the brain.

One correction though; the Aurelia doesn't use yamanaka factors to revert to cellular immaturity. The work by Sinclair's group in treating the retina using tet-dependent expression of 3/4 factors is amazing though, and hopefully could be used to replicate the 'at will' reversion of ageing (as shown by the Aurelia) at some point. I've spent years explaining the effects of ageing, genetic and environmental factors to combat senescence, but this did a better job of anything I could have done in 20 minutes!

Here's a paper describing the Aurelia life cycle:
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2013.12.003

As more than 95% of all metabolic effects induced in mice (by various means) aren't reproduced in humans, it's naive in the extreme to extrapolate from a mouse-model study to anything relating to human physiology. No doubt such wild claims help secure RO1 grants, but they aren't the basis for believing we have a "recipe" for longevity. That said, the atrocious toxic modern diet is clearly sub-optimal, the average person gets far too little meaningful exercise, and so any improvements in lifestyle will lead to a longer health-span if not actually a longer life-span.

I do believe he said something about sugar as well. I keep (well try to keep) my blood glucose as low as possible. After meals in the high 90's. Midway between meals between 50-70. My body does not use glucose for fuel any longer. Instead it relies on ketones for energy. There are few cells in the body that require glucose for fuel. The only two that comes to mind is hemoglobin, and carcinomas. Red blood cells and cancer cells. They both have something in common, lack of mitochondria. So they need glucose to ferment their energy. Ketones cant be fermented, and the mitochondria can use the ketones very efficiently.

Hmm..I have serious doubts about the real practicality of this method of turning genes on and off, to reset them back to how they used to be. For instance, say you have some 70 or 90 year old person and you want to do this, well exactly HOW do you UN DO all those years of DNA damage ? because believe it or not, you cannot ignore all the various ways your DNA is altered over time by the environment...you can avoid X-rays all you like, but unless you carry around a one foot thick lead umbrella for your whole life you will get a constant barrage of ionising radiation from the sun and cosmic rays from interstellar space, then you got the Earth's natural radiation, Radon might be higher where you live, then there's all the chemical species that mutate DNA, like reactive oxygen, industrial contaminants, countless other organic compounds in food, drinks etc, there's also the other biological factors like viruses, plasmids etc etc. So with a copy of your DNA that has a cumulative amount of errors over a lifetime, and thus not a good copy to work back from, this can't be done.

Aged related diseases. They're only age related in so far as they need a long time to develop. The human body does not degenerate into metabolically harmful states over night. No, chronic disease, the big four killers: cancer, diabetes, CVD and neurodegenerative disease are lifestyle induced. The standard western diet is the biggest killer on the planet.

The 'thing' Prof. Sinclair talked about at 11:15, is called autophagy. The body is able to metabolize its own waste and it does that in periods of fasting. What is not exactly true/optimal is to restrict amino acids. First, both mice and monkeys received a diet typical for captivity, which is unnaturally high in sugars. It's like comparing cars that run on diesel, yet are fueled in part by gasoline. One car with a diet of 1% gas versus the other of 5% gas. The whole premise is off, the conclusion invalid.

Moreover, a diet higher in amino acids (= more actual nutrition) allows for more extended periods of fasting, compared to a lower protein diet, that is as a consequence naturally higher in carbs. Carbs are terrible for longevity, protein isn't. A basic note that relates: if you're ever hungry on an intermittened fasting regime, you're eating not enough of the right stuff: meat, fish, eggs and dairy.

I found this super interesting and it lead me down quite a rabbit hole... In the end I learned a couple of things. First... this guy is awash with attempts to commercially benefit from his research. Here's a good summary. https://khn.org/news/a-fountain-of-youth-pill-sure-if-youre-a-mouse/ There are some red flags in there but nothing overtly damning. Second... current published research suggests that NMN is not able to be absorbed into cells, and is broken down into NR before being absorbed and metabolized into the useful compounds. NR is likely to be just as bioavailible, and has a large body of mouse research behind it supporting it's potential at preventing age related disease... in mice. All said, I'm glad this guy is out there doing this research... but be conscious of the fact that he really does want to sell you a pill, despite his efforts to make it sound otherwise. In the arc of 3 hours I went from wanting to load my elderly family members up with the stuff, to being resigned to the fact that... we still need more research.

Aging is basically the wear and tear on the body catching up with you. As time progresses, your body has a harder and harder time keeping up with repairs. DNA gets damaged, things get rebuilt improperly, and mutations may occur. Death is when something in your body is so damaged or mis-repaired that it stops working good enough to support your life.


My view on extending life is that there are a few ways it could be done.
1) One way is to get enough knowledge on how the body repairs itself and how exactly it fails in repairing itself over time then finding ways to "fix it". Some parts of the body repair very slowly or even not at all, so those areas you might need artificial replacements for whenever they go bad.


2) Another way is to go the cyborg/robot route and start replacing "broken parts" with manmade parts. Artificial heart, lungs, liver, kidneys, bones, pretty much everything can have an artificial version, yes, even the brain. Of course, our technology isn't there yet.


3) Yet another option is to consider extracting whatever it is that makes us "us" and implanting it into a virtual world where we can "live forever". We really can't prove one way or another that we aren't already in such a world and that the death simulation is there to keep us thinking we are not in a simulation and we simply get "transplanted" into a new "body" afterward to continue life.


Personally, I like the cyborg route. If it were possible, I would totally transplant myself into a robot shell. If anything ever breaks, simply replace it. If anything ever gets outdated, upgrade it. You will have no need for anything from the environment meaning you could travel space with no issues so long as you have spare parts and electricity. You could even have multiple full replacements for your robotic shell on standby to hop into should anything major go wrong with your current robot shell. One big drawback is the lack of ability to have sex, but the feelings of sex could be simulated I'm sure.
If the 2 modes are "Grow and Reproduce" and "Protect and Repair", does having sex induce you towards the first mode? Is celibacy good for longevity?

p.s. Generally, moving away from dense urban population is the right start; reducing social stressors, and pollutants. The catch is, to live longer one must forgo convenience and slow down the pace of their life. Hence why many remote places (especially small islands) have older populations living simple lives. But then again, isn't walking a mile and running a mile still covering a mile? A primitive style, labor intensive lifestyle allows one to live longer but with less time and resources for non-self-sustenance, self actualization activities; alternatively I can make a living, get food, pay the bills etc, without leaving my bed, so if I invest the remainder of the time/energy in pursuing a passion that is also socially and morally beneficial, I can achieve the same as someone who lives 2-3 times as long but only had a small portion of their day to pursue the same goal. If you're spending 5hrs+ a day on "entertainment", the real problem is the opportunity cost; i.e. What you could have done with that time given the technology and resources at your disposal. There is a lack of some understandings here. These things are part of age sure.
The main reason we age is this:
We do not have systems in our body to repair all types of damage.
Regardless of what you do in genes, genome, or DNA this doesn't help with all the types of age damage.
Example:
Heart attacks become more likely with age due to plac accumulating outside the arteries throughout life. As it becomes too much it bursts into the artery goes to the heart and cause heart attacks.
Even if you deal with DNA and genomes and telomeres, you also need to deal with the other types of damage.
The right way to view ageing is that it isn't a process that "is" ageing
*It's just damage. *
The way to deal with ageing as a whole is to create regular general therapies for the various general types of damage that are created.
That way no mater what in the body causes ageing, since it's regularly removed medically we'll stay ahead of the problem without the issue becoming more and more complex over time.

There are two problems with slowing aging:
1- Overpopulation : the longer we live, the longer we populate the limited in resources Earth. If we live twice longer, we have twice as many generations living together, so we double the population and double the environmental destruction.

I think this is a big gap in the philosophy of contemporary science, "should we?"/"how should we?" are always intrinsically and organically a part of "can we?" and pretending they are not is probably the primary factor determining if they will ever be addressed. It's a bias in science reporting, not unlike positive-results bias, it's an economic distortion of the work and needs to be acknowledged in more than a cursory way. We study what gets money and nobody wants to hear about how aging may be ideal at some level.

One reason we age, evolutionarily, is likey that it was advantageous to the group. How can we preserve that advantage, if it exists (which people resist studying), while maintaining the benefits of slowing/stopping aging individuallly? "Can we?" is a BS question on its own.

Now, I switch to epigenetics: Even if mice and other mammals have shown to be great models for medicine and human physiology, the similarities are mainly attributed to our shared parts of the genomes. The epigenome is another monster we're talking about, with its own evolutionary history throughout life on Earth. Take insects as an example, which share a lot of similarities regarding genes of enzymes involved in epigenetic processes. Even though they use the same genetic machinery to add/delete and edit epigenetic marks, they use these for very different reasons. Insects use epigenetic landmarks very differently, and that's why you don't see any mammals going through metamorphosis or involved in a larval growth phase (among other things). This is also the case with cloning, and the failure to clone humans. Evidence suggests that this could be because of the asymmetry of genomic imprints of the gametes. Thus requiring a viable male and female complementary imprints that successfully get the embryo machinery going (or both having male and female identical twins as subjects, maybe?).

It’s great see people drawn to aging research.
But a few words of caution :
1) Things that work in mice Or non-human primates don’t necessarily work in humans : https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/cancer-research-points-to-key-unknowns-about-popular-antiaging-supplements/
2) Many of these ‘nutriceuticals’ are not FDA regulated in the same way as a new drug because they are classified as a nutritional supplement.
3) Data is still early, limited and while there appears to be a lot of hype on this topic - be skeptical of anything that sounds too good to be true. Marketing these products is based on the idea of a single cure-all. Body systems are seldom that simple and those who make grand claims about silver bullets (NMN, resveratrol, MTOR inhibition) May have conflicts of interest. That doesn’t make it wrong and shouldn’t disappoint because the potential is exciting. It should be considered when weighing the evidence though.

TLDR- hooman body is complex. One mechanism or drug won’t cure aging

-- Sirtuins: Glycotoxin in food i.e. AGEs correlate to suppression of Sirtuins. AGEs exist mainly in meat products (Reducing Glycotoxin intake to Prevent Alzheimer’s)
-- AMPK: Vinegar or simply a dilute solution of acetic acid, activates an AMPK enzyme. 2 Table spoons of apple cider vinegar a day would do the trick. (Vinegar Is Good for You)

I'm firmly in the "but overpopulation" camp with extended life treatment (we're JUST getting a handle on it now, ffs). But even putting that aside, while this is fascinating, it doesn't excite me for one reason: Mice/Rats/Monkeys are not Humans.

While I'd love to think that we are only a decade away from age slowing or de-aging treatments, until actual human trials of some sort begin, I chose to remain skeptical; too many treatments that were promising in animals have come up short in humans for me to be anything else.

And I'm not referring to side effects, either; that's a whole other issue that I'm confident we can deal with when the time comes (supplemental treatments to mitigate, for example). I focus purely on "does it work in humans" with my skepticism.

Still, learning about what we can (or already) do to prevent aging is cry useful, so thank you for that!

Well, what's quite obvious is that the given cause of aging, or its interpretation, is not very significant in humans because, if it was, people who live in inhospitable conditions, are malnourished, or both, would live significantly longer than the rest (significantly longer being at least 200 years on average or something - a couple of years here and there cannot be a proof because simple lifestyle choices like doing sports, smoking or drinking alcohol, can make that difference). Longevity does not cause population to explode.  This misconception is repeated so often.   Population is measured in doubling times.  That is p0 2^n.  If parents died immediately after having children, then population would be p0 2^n.   If no one ever died, then population would be  p0 Sum[ {i, 1,n}, 2^n)  =  p0 (2^(n+1) - 1).   I.e. just shy of what the population would have been anyway just one generation later.  There is no overpopulation danger with immortality.  Rather, the dominant factor is how many children people have per generation.

Moon jellyfish don’t live longer than a year on average. The polyp stage of their lifespan can live a fair amount of time, but their genetics breaks down and mutations occur after so many replications. There are a few jellyfish, such a particular Japanese one, that can revert to a polyp and go through their lifecycle again, refreshing the majority of their cells and resetting the genetics , but moon jellyfish cannot. They can regenerate, and the do have senescence only through genetic fatigue. However, it is likely to be possible to reduce genetic deviation and damage over time by bolstering genetic supports and improving the removal and replacement of senescent cells. Corals and anemones are capable of living for thousands of years by cloning themselves in a colony setting. Epigenetics are fascinating and I highly recommend casual people take a look at it. It can affect everything from heart disease to mental capacity later in life as well as your kids lives. Stress events and long term danger are known especially to cause significant effects. I read a study that if you have genetic disposition to be an alcoholic, by avoiding substance abuse it can drastically reduce your child’s risk by actually changing the gene expression.

So I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes a few years ago.  If this kind of epigenetic therapy were applied to my pancreas and my liver, could it theoretically cure me, by resetting those organs to a state before I had diabetes?  It seems to me that even if a whole body Gene therapy isn't practical these targeted therapies could still cure many different chronic illnesses.  Not only is there a roadmap to the technology to reverse aging, but each step on that path may save lives on its own.  That's more than a roadmap, that's the type of pathway natural selection takes, only allowing forward steps that improve reproduction.  I'm getting speculative here, but if each step forward saves lives and presumably makes money for the developers, could we forestall this technology even if we wanted to?  If he's right about the epigenetic role, then this technology is probably inevitable eventually.

The position the professor takes that hair growing in new places on the body is indicative of cells failing to operate correctly is not held out by the contextual evidence - namely that that example follows a pattern across much of the population.  Rather than suggesting this hair growth is a symptom of cells “forgetting” their purpose, this implies that the described hair growth indicates a prescribed stage of development; stage, not age.  If cells were behaving radically and irregularly differently, not systematically presenting across the population in a readily predictable fashion, that would suggest cells repurposing.

It feels like biology is truly the next massive step in the 'evolution' of our capabilities as a species. If we can 'hack' the genome, there's no end to what we could accomplish. Nature and billions of years of evolution have fine-tuned the potential of creatures to an impossible level. Honestly, the possibility of giving people longer, healthier lives is just the tip of the iceberg. We could give people what amounts to superpowers, in theory. We could potentially some day get around the 'automated' systems in the body that cause parts to atrophy when not in use, and stop the excessive buildup of fat storage, or at least make the body prioritize that fat storage more actively. We could activate our innate ability to change our perception of the passage of time and make it accessible via conscious effort. Anything that any human has been shown to physically be able to do, from withstanding incredible heat or cold for extended time to amazing feats of strength or resilience, it's all technically feasible, if completely out of the realm of what we can even think of doing right now. It seems like we're on that path, and it's really exciting to think that our species could become something greater like that. It could make it that much more possible to one day have humans create a new colony among the stars. I don't even care if it's something that has to start at birth, and I never get to enjoy the benefits of this advancement personally. If we can make the species better, more likely to continue our survival in a happier and non-harmful way, I absolutely want that for the coming generations.


What if we had computers that were brains? Brains that were computers? What if we found a totally different way to get the energy we need for our bodies? What if we didn't need sleep? What if we never got sick or old? Maybe much of this is a pipe dream, but I'm really hopeful that we'll have a future where people are no longer saddled with some of the greater horrors of life, and maybe are enabled to live lives that are not only happier and healthier for themselves, but with a better relationship with our planet and its ecosystems.

12:40 - The monkey experiment was later revised by other studies who showed that the problem with the restricted diet monkeys were that they were compared to overweight monkeys who couldn't exercise properly, and lack a balanced diet, not healthy ones. When you compare restricted diet monkeys with healthy "balanced" diet monkeys, the difference of life span seen between the two groups was minor, with a slight advantage in favour of the healthy ones. Considering that healthy balanced diet monkeys had more muscle, more energy, better cognitive abilities, I would not advocate for a restricted diet.

Obviously we can live forever. If we just think about how to rebirth ourselves.
Because at the end of the day, we give birth to new life that will live another lifespan years in perpetuity.
The whole cycle of sex, pregnancy and birth isn't magic. We combine two DNA's to create an offspring that starts fresh. We could do the same outside of the bedroom, creating a new body to live in.

The problem as always is morality. Is the body regarded as a separate life form?
The other problem is, we simply haven't figured out how to move to the new body. The brain ages with the rest of our body and simply re-connecting to a new body won't solve that problem.

And at the end of it all, do we even really want to live forever? We should be asking ourselves if death is such a bad thing? If we've enjoyed full lives already, do we really need to extend that into the forever? At what point do you get bored of the same old. At what point do we say "hey, it's time we let the next generation experience life without being burdened with our own experiences"?

The real problem with death is that we are genetically hotwired to fear dying, pain or even misery. If we already knew beforehand that we die on mm/dd yyyy at hh:mm:ss and that it will be completely painless and the end of everything we consider our own conscience, then we most likely wouldn't feel so bad about it. Dr. Ahmad Samir aljada (Professor of biochemistry at Alfaisal University) at aaljada@alfaisal.edu

According to him; he has been doing research on the effects of resveratrol on aging (for 15 years).

From what I've understood resveratrol works on inhibiting something that has to do with histone acetylation or histone deacetylation.

The thing that is inhibited by resveratrol will decrease the rate of gene expression. Gene expression is important for making proteins which is essential for cell structure, and the synthesis of many important hormones and chemicals in the body.

The decrease of gene expression would just only slow things down; thus, from what I've understood, will decrease the rate of aging. According to professor Ahmed, that is why some people claim that the Mediterranean diet which, includes red wine, is "good for health" because "it makes you age slower"; due to the presence of resveratrol in red wine.

You need to go back and recheck your claim about protein. The fact is that mTor is actived by ingestion of certain amino acids but mTor is a binary switch: it is either activated or suppressed. So if you eat ANY protein it is activated. In other words it is detecting whether you're eating anything (containing protein) and suppressed when you're fasting (or in a famine). So you make an incorrect leap by saying "eat less protein." If you ate a little protein frequently then your mTor is activated all the time regardless of the total amount. Also, the research shows that 1. muscle loss in the elderly correlates with risk of death, 2. the elderly need to eat more protein in order to maintain muscle mass because their protein absorption is less efficient.

I'm going to attempt to address such concerns.

Overpopulation - Through things like space colonization, arcologies(cities primarily or exclusively inside massive skyscrapers and other buildings ), vertical farming, etc, we could alleviate the problems of lack of space and resources.

Inequality - Societies already have income and wealth inequality and likely always will. This is a feature of all political and economic systems, capitalism, socialism and communism, social democracy, etc. Of course, radical life extension isn't going to be cheap, but their might be loans,grants and charities available to help most people afford it

Death is natural - But then again, so are disease and the inability of humans to fly, but we've been fighting and\or altering nature for thousands of years.

Living for hundreds or thousands of years would mean being frail and bedridden most of that time - WRONG! The whole idea is to extend not only lifespans, but also the portion of those lifespans spent in good health. In fact, life extension of any kind involves increasing healthspan.

Took this from the HuffPost : "Despite his enthusiasm, published scientific research has not yet demonstrated the molecule works in humans as it does in mice. Sinclair, however, has a considerable financial stake in his claims being proven correct, and has lent his scientific prowess to commercializing possible life extension products such molecules known as “NAD boosters.”

His financial interests include being listed as an inventor on a patent licensed to Elysium Health, a supplement company that sells a NAD booster in pills for $60 a bottle. He’s also an investor in InsideTracker, the company that he says measured his age."

I only took a portion of the article so I encourage anyone interested to read the whole article.

As I said, the field deserves some more studies, it would be awesome if it worked on humans too, but it hasn't been proven yet. I feel uneasy with the link between his research and the products he sells.

I don't want to badmouth him so I won't say he's a charlatan or anything (and maybe he's really enthusiatic and honest), but as long as I don't have any evidence that it works on human I'll choose to doubt.

I'll first start off by saying I am a big fan of the channel and that this is an incredibly interesting topic; however, giving out an advice such as "eat less protein" without much context can be harmful, not to mention it ignores a whole lot of data we have regarding protein being the most satiating nutrient (as in it can aid in maintaining caloric restriction and a healthy body weight) and that increased muscle mass (via resistance training+adequate protein intake) is strongly linked to an improved quality of life (especially in the older population), along with many other health benefits. Many elderly people suffer from decreased muscle mass and bone density, and reducing their (most likely already-low) dietary protein intake even more is not a good idea. Could it help slow down aging? We can't even say that for sure, but even if so - how will this slower aging look like? What's the point of living longer if the quality of life is dramatically reduced? I, personally, don't know if I'd want to extend my lifespan knowing that I'll be quite disabled or not as independent as I could be had I done things differently. The TL;DR is that the data currently suggests that a high protein intake is safe and actually required in order to support the demands imposed on the body from physical activity. In addition to that, saying "eat less" can also be harmful without any context, as (I assume) there's a huge diversity in the audience seeing this video, and some of this audience may actually be calorie/nutrient-deprived. While it is true that the obesity epidemic keeps growing and becomes a bigger problem, we cannot make such bold, general statements on a public platform with that large of an audience.  I'll just conclude by saying (again) that I'm a big VT fan, and that this isn't an attack or anything, but rather a call for responsibility-check and perhaps correcting some mistakes found in the video, or at least showing the bigger picture.

Around 7:40 they are talking about hair growing in different places as you grow older. There is no way this has anything to do with individual cells 'forgetting' what they were. I like his hypothesis and think it can explain some phenomenon, but hair growing? No. To grow a hair takes hundreds and thousands of cells working together around a follicle and producing a long chain of keratin/protein, a single hair. Cancerous tumors are the perfect example of this phenomenon, where a cell forgets its supposed to die, or at least not grow, and it grows out of control, destroying the adjacent cells in the process. Maybe skin blotches or failing eyesight and hearing could also be explained through this phenomenon, and probably a few other examples if I thought about it any more than typing up a comment, but he's lost me here. I hope this is just a great oversimplification he's using as a tool to help explain the phenomenon.

If DNA methylation, or I guess the dysregulation of DNA methylation, is a marker of biological aging, what is the link between vitamin B12 and aging? Methylcobalamin (MeCb) is the active vitamer, or co-enzyme, that helps regulate DNA methylation. The other active vitamer, adenosylcobalamin (AdCb), is important for the upkeep of neurological remyelination (essentially, the myelin sheath surrounding white matter gets damaged, and AdCb is the co-enzyme that helps repair the myelin). There are two other vitamers (hydroxocobalamin or OHCb, and cyanocobalamin or CNCb), which are inactive, meaning they play no role in enzyme functionality - however all four vitamers are interchangeable.
B12 deficiency has really terrible outcomes - neurological effects such as dementia, or even coma and death from AdCb deficiency, and pernicious anemia from MeCb deficiency. On the flipside, excess B12 is stored (AdCb in somatic mitochondria and MeCb in the liver) - in fact, you can have up to four years' worth of excess B12 stored in your liver, since around 95% of your used cobalamin is recycled. However, anything in excess of that ~four year mass of vitamin B12 will be excreted in your urine or feces.
I was wondering if there was a known link between the mass storage of vitamin B12 in the liver and the biomarker of aging through dysregulation of DNA methylation. In other words, is unnecessary supplementation of B12 bad for your healthspan?

I can cite sources if anyone's interested & elaborate more information on the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of vitamin B12

The theory: all electrochemical states leave traces that make that state likely to happen again. Remembering is when current electro-chemical state falls n line with a old state and so we re-create the memory based on the mental state when the memory was formed. So all activity leaves 3D traces that strengthen some connections, make new ones, or weaken connections which then encourages a later brain state to fall into the same patterns that were established when the memory was formed.
