Okay. So in videogames we've had progressive generation / random generation for a long time. "The world is progressively generated", you know this from Terraria, Minecraft and so forth.
Now, in these games each generated world has what we call a seed. That is, a specific set of conditions that will produce that exact world again, or a world that is considerably similar so that you can control for specific eventualities (such as, say, in world 1001 there is no iron, but in world 1002 there is. We would select not to have World 1001 because iron is important, thus selecting for specific variables).


Okay back to genes, cancer and so forth. What if when we're born, our unique DNA is such a "seed"? What if those people who live to old age simply had a seed that ruled out those things which correlate with mortality at a younger age, and by definition have therefore selected for things like cancer which will manifest only after X generations?


That's just specific cancers, but there's loads of causes, not all informed by genetics in the form of genetic damage, but by congenital factors and even disparately connected factors like diet, habits and environment: Working in a coal mine increases your odds of lung cancer - however, it takes a specific kind of person to WANT to work in a coal mine to begin with. Is the coal mine causing cancer, or is the behavior and temperament of the individual which causes interest in working in a coal mine, which are informed by genetics as well, causing the cancer?

What is aging? Every life is made with an expiration date. It can be found in your genes. The structures at the end of your chromosomes, that cap your DNA, are known as Telomeres. These telomeres can be measured and can be observed reducing throughout one's life. For this reason, they are used at biomarkers for aging. These telomeres are assembled during your infant development. Many, many, many factors play in the LENGTH of telomeres you are designated, but an understanding must be made that after infancy, these telomeres STOP growing and START deteriorating.
Us meditators have been unfortunately brushed under the rug per se and scientists have difficulties stepping out of their own concretized assumptions. But we have been employing methods for extending telomere longevity for over 32 thousand years. Meditation also allows one to activate repressed genetic expressions that can actually GROW telomere length. This is naturally ingrained in our physiology, nothing supernatural about it.

Hey Derek, very interesting topic indeed. Just some precautions you should take, or some caveats that you perhaps might add: when you start to dabble in medical sciences, you learn very quickly that there is a world of things that go between biological and clinical physiology. Therefore, you might add that the idea of intermittent fasting or reduced protein consumption, extreme temperature and training have not be clinically proven (and might never be, given the power the study would need, and the weak monetary incentive).

Same goes for the application of 'mice-based therapy' to humans. We can cure Parkinson's or Alzheimer's, even blindness in some mice, but the translation to humans never worked. It might be because we are working on mice that are 'modelled' to express certain diseases, which do not reflect a 'real' genetically diverse population, but it surely is because there is also a world of differences (in genetics & epigenetics) between the mouse and humans. The same can be said with studies on monkeys actually, even though they are much much closer in terms of genetics.

Great topic of discussion anyways. In hopes that you will make another series of videos on biological and medical subjects,
Cheers

This is all very interesting. But lets keep in mind that all this research is in its infancy. Most of the statements made have a WIDE confidence interval. For example, at about the 9 minute mark you'll hear him say his cells are 60 years old or 31 years old... While that may be the age the calculation spit out the confidence interval is likely VERY WIDE (meaning + or - a certain amount). Furthermore, the more we research a problem (say... hypertension or diabetes) the more we find out that the problem is multifactorial. The point is this, the last thing we need is another "fad" with aging or dieting or etc. The problems aren't this simple. Be cautious when interpreting this data. But... like I said in the beginning I'm very interested and I'll continue to read the literature as it comes out (for those who would like to know where to get literature - try PubMed - NOT GOOGLE)

As a note, this lab is not the only lab working on this. There are dozens of other teams that have promising results in preventing and reversing aging. Including one that has already gone through Stage 1 clinical trials. Many are using different methods to prevent different causes (as mentioned in the video there are 8-9 known causes of aging) so the entire known process of aging may be cured around the same time even if individual treatments by single teams prove to not be enough by themselves. I say known because I imagine that we’ll start to have to worry about new age-related problems when we get older that we don’t because we die so young. The big one I can foresee is the brain reaching its storage capacity (currently unknown how many years it can store), which we could find out happens around a century, or perhaps we can get a full millennium out of it. Neuralink or other BMI could likely help provide solutions to that problem though. Still it’s likely we’ll find some other problems, but if we get even an extra two decades from current treatments, then that’s an extra two decades to cure those problems before they become problems. In other words, there is a relatively good chance that in two decades those who are alive and can afford the medicine can expect to live however long they desire. The big question then is who will be able to afford it. At first we can fully expect that these drugs will be quite expensive. Depending on the nature of them though, they may still be something that middle-class residents may be able to afford, especially if they are of the type that reverses significant parts of aging with minimal drug application, a kind of drug you may only need to take every 50 years or so, longer if you live healthily. Considering it may be possible to leave retirement with such drugs, it may be worth it to get a small loan if needed then get work to pay it off and prepare for the next round. Any that require constant administration would likely be something only the very rich or very determined could afford at first, but even without those many could gain decades through the other drugs that could help them better afford these drugs if they use the money set aside for retirement to help them through school or training themselves. And of course how many people can afford it will depend on how quickly these drugs go generic. Considering that there could be lots of patented drugs that are doing different things to arrive at the same destination, we could have actual competition as well that’ll bring down prices before they go generic, in theory at least. And of course worse case scenario you could just move to Canada or something if you’re in the US.

The problems we imagine when we think about people living forever are simply transitional problems. As our reality changes our behavior does too. Population explosions usually happen when a society gets better medical care and the mortality rate of infants is drastically reduced. But it eventually levels out over a generation. I'd imagine something similar would happen if we became virtually immortal (accidents happen) as a species. Births would become as rare as deaths.
On top of that we're now at a point where we can start engineering artificial habitats in space. Using only the resources found in our solar system we can easily grow a population a billion times larger than what we have now and still have more space for every individual than we have now.

It's better if we just age later, rather than necessarily extending the average life span by much more. So, in other words, aging happens later, but much more rapidly. Extending the life span too much is unnatural, and will lead to overpopulation due to the limited resources on the planet.

The problem with longevity is humans are not resource-conscious. They destroy their environment at an alarming rate. Genetic research is great to enhance longevity however manipulation of genetic material to stop or prevent illness is difficult at best. The human body expresses wear from the inception of life. We are designed to be finite, not infinite. We have DNA that has not even been expressed, and or utilized. The strand is such a length that further research is required.

Another point of view:
Consciousness and life inside any living being are always evolving. Old cells that cannot be transformed to embody the upgraded consciousness need to die, in order to make room for new "updated" cells. This is true for any living organism. When the body runs out of fuel, and cannot create new cells it will go through the process that we call "dead".
Funny enough computers replicate this process quite well :) Software updates can be applied to a certain point, beyond that a hardware upgrade is required to install new functionalities.

This is like discussing the question, “Can we make an atom bomb?” Some science should be left alone and pushing the discussion in our world is irresponsible. It will absolutely mean health for the rich and death for the poor. As long as there is a monetary system this science will only help the wealthy. Can you imagine a world where Donald Trump will never die? Where the Clinton dynasty is eternal?

This is definitely going to be controversial, but I personally feel both sides make very valid points, standing for or against the idea of slowing, halting and/or reversing aging. There is certainly truth to the claim that it would further draw a divide between the wealthy and the poor, as the sheer disparity in lifespan and healthspan would be made even more apparent. But at the same time, the extension of life could be the solution to many problems we face. A lot of things we wish to see to fruition usually take generations of people just to manifest, whether it be cultural paradigm shifts, scientific discoveries or the convincing of people that thiccness isn’t the same as being fat. If we just had more time, perhaps it would be easier to achieve these goals. After all, those who initiate such movements would have the time to spur them on. Just take Stephen Hawking’s untimely death one year prior to the first black hole image as an example.

Even on the more micro scale, it could hold many benefits for the common man. We would have more time to spend with loved ones, more time to figure out what we are truly passionate about, more time to find our ikigai (Japanese term for “reason for being”) and more time to just live. Often we’re so caught up in the minutiae of life because we’re always afraid of not having enough time for everything. But by halting aging, we could change all of this. It’s just my opinion, but I personally feel that stopping aging wouldn’t be a bad thing if utilized well. As very aptly said by CGP grey, humans will not miss the reaper of death and construct one, just as we do not mix water and waste now that we are able to separate them. Derek did say to leave this discussion for the comments, so I thought I’d give my two cents :)

I want to mention the ethical aspect of these studies :

1. It is more than likely that the first few trials will fail. Either resulting in miscarriages or resulting in a child who suffers from un-studied new genetic diseases, or dying at a young age.

2. If these studies were proven to be effective, who decides who gets the benefit of these treatments

3. Most theoretical anti-aging treatments act on chromosomal telomeres. We will need to increase the activity of telomerase to stop this aging. However these telomerase changes have been associated with various forms of cancer

4. If a person gets benefits of these studies, they are likely to be from the first world. Or atleast someone affluent. These people have 1-2 children on average, usually much less than replacement rates. Thus, if someone's genetics or epigenetics are changed due to these studies, it is not likely that the new genes would survive in the gene pool in the future. That basically just means that these treatments won't last through a lot of generations and probably won't impact humanity in the long term. It would just cause another population explosion in the short term, due to reduced death rates.
